newsitem.title: USA: Chiles says tobacco issue long way from settlement.
newsitem.headline: Chiles says tobacco issue long way from settlement.

text.p: Gov. Lawton Chiles on Wednesday his state was a long way from a settlement with tobacco giants R.J. Reynolds and Philip Morris and Florida's Medicaid lawsuit would go forward as planned.

At a news conference in the state capital, Chiles confirmed that Florida Attorney-General Bob Butterworth was involved in negotiations with the tobacco companies. But he said the state's $1 billion lawsuit, scheduled for trial in West Palm Beach in August, would not be derailed.
"I think this is a small step along a long and very uncertain path," Chiles said of the negotiations. "From what I can understand, we are a long way from a settlement agreement."

Butterworth is one of 22 state attorneys-general suing tobacco companies, including R.J. Reynolds, a unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp and Philip Morris Cos Inc, seeking to recoup costs of treating sick smokers.
Several attorneys general said Wednesday they were negotiating with tobacco executives on a possible settlement of massive litigation against the industry.
"They've been meeting quite a bit, we know that," Chiles said. "I'm sure they have made some kind of progress."

In order for Florida to consider a settlement, Chiles said, tobacco companies would have to make drastic changes in marketing and drop advertising aimed at children. "We just have to be assured that children would not only not be targeted, but that they would be protected," he said.

Until the childrens' issue is settled, no agreement would be possible, he said. "That's our number one concern. We have to be satisfied with that before we talk about the liability angles and some of the other things."
A settlement would also probably involve some type of immunity for the tobacco companies in return for payments over a 20-30 year period, he said.
